tagged_story_for_tts:
**Two ways to think. One fast, one slow.**

The title *Thinking, Fast and Slow* comes from psychologist Daniel Kahneman’s discovery that our brains operate like two pilots: **System 1** (fast, automatic) and **System 2** (slow, effortful). The names describe their speed—not their smarts.

Most people assume good decisions come from careful thought. But Kahneman’s work—rooted in decades of experiments with Amos Tversky—showed how often we trust **System 1’s shortcuts**, even when they mislead us. Example: If someone asks, *"Is 2 + 2 = 5?"*, your brain rejects it instantly (System 1). But solving *17 × 24* forces you to pause and calculate (System 2). The first feels easy; the second feels like work.

These shortcuts aren’t random. They’re **cognitive biases**—patterns like *"anchoring"* (relying too much on the first number you hear) or *"loss aversion"* (fearing losses more than valuing gains). In one test, doctors given the same patient data recommended surgery 72% of the time when told *"90% survival rate"* but only 50% when told *"10% mortality rate."* Same facts, different framing—System 1 reacted to the words, not the math.

The book’s power isn’t just exposing flaws; it’s showing how to **spot them in action**. A trader might avoid selling a losing stock because *"it’ll rebound"* (System 1’s optimism), while System 2 would check the data. Or a job interviewer might hire someone *"with a firm handshake"* (a bias called the *"halo effect"*) instead of reviewing their resume.

Kahneman’s experiments proved these errors aren’t rare—they’re **built into how we think**. Even chess masters, when shown a board with pieces placed randomly, will suggest *"strong"* moves for positions that don’t exist. Their System 1 recognizes patterns; it doesn’t question them.

This isn’t about dumb vs. smart. It’s about **when to trust your gut—and when to slow down**. A fire alarm’s blare needs System 1. Choosing a mortgage needs System 2. The trick? Noticing which pilot is flying.

What else shapes our choices without us realizing? **How memory tricks us into rewriting the past. Why experts overestimate their predictions. The hidden math behind "good enough" decisions.**
